paper.title: Evidence for the utility of quantum computing before fault tolerance

comparisons.description: Unmitigated magnetization M_z decays monotonically with Trotter depth due to noise accumulation

emulator.failure_description: Noisy M_z decays from 0.972 (d=1) to 0.755 (d=10) on 9-qubit Tuna-9 topology with p=0.01 depolarizing noise. Monotonic decay matches paper's observation on 127 qubits.

comparisons.description: ZNE error mitigation recovers ideal M_z at Clifford point (theta_h=0) across depths

emulator.failure_description: ZNE with gate folding (factors 1,3,5) and Richardson extrapolation recovers M_z to within 3.0% of ideal at depth 10. Max ZNE error 0.030 vs noisy error 0.245. At depth 1, ZNE error is only 0.002%.

comparisons.description: ZNE error mitigation substantially improves accuracy over unmitigated results

emulator.failure_description: ZNE achieves 14.1x improvement over unmitigated results (ZNE MAE 0.010 vs noisy MAE 0.141). Paper reported ~10x with PEA on 127 qubits. Our basic ZNE on 9 qubits achieves higher improvement likely due to simpler noise landscape at smaller scale.
emulator.note: Paper used PEA (learned Pauli-Lindblad noise model). We use basic ZNE gate folding, which is simpler but effective at 9-qubit scale.

scaling_notes.original_mitigation: PEA with learned Pauli-Lindblad noise model
scaling_notes.key_difference: Physics is identical (kicked Ising Trotterization), but scale and mitigation sophistication differ. 9 qubits is classically exactly simulable, providing ground truth. 127 qubits is in the regime where classical methods struggle.
scaling_notes.classical_controversy: Tindall et al. (2024) showed tensor network methods can reproduce 127-qubit results with higher accuracy. At 9 qubits, classical simulation is trivial, making this a test of the mitigation method rather than quantum advantage.

depth_sweep_data.description: M_z vs Trotter depth at theta_h=0 (Clifford), 9 qubits, depolarizing p=0.01

theta_sweep_data.description: M_z vs theta_h at depth=5, 9 qubits, depolarizing p=0.01

summary.notes: All 3 claims PASS on emulator with simulated noise. 9-qubit kicked Ising on Tuna-9 topology with depolarizing noise p=0.01. ZNE gate folding provides 14.1x improvement. Key physics reproduced: noise accumulates with depth, ZNE recovers ideal at Clifford, ZNE substantially outperforms unmitigated. Hardware runs on Tuna-9 and IBM Torino planned as next step.
